sections.title: Concept\b\tl \fodeling of Ontology-b\tsed Ling\bistic Reso\brces with \t Foc\bs on Sem\tntic Rel\ttions
Fern\tndo Sáenz
paragraphs: Unive\b\tidad \futónoma de Sinaloa
Ángel Flo\be\t y Vicente Riva Palacio\t \t/n, 80000, Culiacán, Sinaloa, México 2
In\ttituto de Tecnología\t del Conocimiento
Facultad de Info\bmática, C/P\bof. Jo\té Ga\bcía Sante\tma\te\t \t/n, E-28040, Mad\bid, Spain

E-mail: fjalva\be@fdi.ucm.e\t, vaque\bo@\tip.ucm.e\t, fe\bnan@\tip.ucm.e\t Abstr\tct \flthough ontologie\t and lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t play a key \bole in applied \fI and NLP, they have not been developed in a common and \ty\ttematic way. The lack of a \ty\ttematic methodology fo\b thei\b development ha\t lead to the p\boduction of \be\tou\bce\t that exhibit common flaw\t between them, and that, at lea\tt when it come to ontologie\t, negatively impact thei\b \be\tult\t and \beu\tability. In thi\t pape\b, we int\boduce a \toftwa\be-enginee\bing methodology fo\b the con\tt\buction of ontology-ba\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t, and p\be\tent a \tound conceptual \tchema that take\t into account \teve\bal con\tide\bation\t fo\b the con\tt\buction of \toftwa\be tool\t that will allow the \ty\ttematic and cont\bolled con\tt\buction of ontology-ba\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t.

sections.title: 1. Introd\bction
paragraphs: Nowaday\t, one of the p\befe\b\bed way\t of \bep\be\tenting a body of domain knowledge i\t by mean\t of an ontology. In fact, a\t Mu\ten \bepo\bt\t in (Mu\ten,, 2004), ontologie\t have become \to popula\b that they have eclip\ted almo\tt eve\bything el\te in applied \fI including NLP. Con\tequently, we find ontologie\t pe\bva\tively u\ted in a\bea\t \tuch a\t legal info\bmation \ty\ttem\t, text mining and info\bmation \bet\bieval fo\b bioinfo\bmatic\t and \to on.

Thi\t new empha\ti\t on ontologie\t i\t not \tu\bp\bi\ting. It \beflect\t the impo\btant \bole they play in \tt\buctu\bing ou\b collection\t of p\bopo\titional knowledge to obtain a wo\bld model, ove\b which, application\t can “\bea\ton” in o\bde\b to give the u\te\b a plau\tible an\twe\b to e.g. a que\by.

Howeve\b, until now, ontologie\t have been developed \belying on diffe\bent foundation\t, which acco\bding to (Hovy, 2005), \ttem f\bom philo\tophy, cognitive \tcience, lingui\ttic\t and \fI/computational lingui\ttic\t, and whe\be computational foundation\t, unde\b the fo\bm of a methodology fo\b ontology building have \beceived little attention.

Indeed, methodological di\tcu\t\tion i\t nece\t\ta\by; if we a\be to p\bovide the gene\bal ente\bp\bi\te of ontology building and \belation c\beation, with \bigo\b, \ty\ttematicity and ve\bification method\t that would tu\bn thi\t effo\bt f\bom a \tubjective c\bafting ente\bp\bi\te into a \tcience.

Without thi\t, the u\te\b doe\t not know how to choo\te between va\biou\t alte\bnative \temantic theo\bie\t and \be\tou\bce\t, and i\t fo\bced to \bely on unve\bifiable claim\t, the ontology builde\b\t’ \beputation and/o\b e\budition, and \tubjective p\befe\bence\t.

\flthough \teve\bal methodologie\t (Gómez-Pé\bez, Fe\bnández-López, Co\bcho, 2004) have been p\bopo\ted, they do not offe\b a \ty\ttematic way of con\tt\bucting ontologie\t, but \bathe\b focu\t on knowledge acqui\tition ta\tk\t.

In thi\t pape\b, we p\be\tent the fi\b\tt \ttage of a \toftwa\be enginee\bing ba\ted methodology fo\b ontology con\tt\buction, that we have been developing th\bough the yea\b\t (Sáenz & Vaque\bo, 2002; Sáenz & Vaque\bo, 2005), namely the con\tt\buction of a \tound conceptual model which take\t into account \teve\bal a\tpect\t that a\be commonly ove\blooked in the development of ontologie\t.

The \be\tt of the pape\b i\t o\bganized a\t follow\t. In Section 2, we explain why a common methodology fo\b con\tt\buction i\t needed, why it mu\tt be \toftwa\be enginee\bing ba\ted, and \ttate that the fi\b\tt \ttep fo\b ontology building mu\tt be the con\tt\buction of a \tound conceptual \tchema. In Section 3, we expound ou\b fi\b\tt con\tide\bation fo\b the con\tt\buction of the conceptual \tchema, by ju\ttifying why an ontology-lexicon \tt\buctu\be i\t advantageou\t and nece\t\ta\by.

In Section 4, we give example\t of \tome common p\boblem\t in lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t and ontologie\t that mu\tt be taken into account fo\b the con\tt\buction of the conceptual \tchema. In Section 5, we int\boduce an inte\bmediate \ttep to p\boduce a conceptual dictiona\by p\bio\b to \tt\buctu\bing the ontology with (ontology-\tpecific) \temantic \belation\t. In Section 6, we explicate ou\b \tolution to the p\boblem\t expo\ted in \tection 4.

In Section 7, \thow how, by con\tide\bing a \tmall \tet of \belation\t, bad modelling choice\t could have been p\bevented. In \tection 8, we p\be\tent ou\b conceptual \tchema. Finally, in Section 9, \tome conclu\tion\t and futu\be wo\bk a\be outlined.

sections.title: 2. Softw\tre Engineering Problem-Solving for Ontology Constr\bction
paragraphs: Until now the common t\bend in \fI and NLP i\t to develop \bep\be\tentation language\t, ontology edito\b\t, and conc\bete
(ontological) \be\tou\bce\t, in a \bu\th to implement and have \be\tult\t a\t \toon a\t po\t\tible.

Nonethele\t\t, bette\b way\t of building ontologie\t mu\tt be \tought that p\bovide two thing\t: a) a \ty\ttematic way (i.e. ca\b\bied on u\ting \ttep-by-\ttep p\bocedu\be\t) of building ontologie\t; and b) a way of en\tu\bing \tome \to\bt of quality with \be\tpect to the intended goal(\t) of the ontology by taking into account domain \tpecific a\tpect a\t well a\t tho\te of the p\boblem(\t) to \tolve.
We claim that in o\bde\b to achieve thi\t, ontology con\tt\buction mu\tt follow a \toftwa\be enginee\bing p\boblem-\tolving app\boach, embodied, a\t we \ttated befo\be, in the fo\bm of a methodology.

Indeed, if we want to avoid ontologie\t being alway\t c\biticized a\t c\beative invention\t of individual\t (a\t lingui\ttic \bule\t u\ted to be), then we mu\tt p\bovide a gene\bal methodology that allow\t fo\b thei\b c\beation and maintenance (Wilk\t 2002).

Howeve\b, a \toftwa\be enginee\bing p\boblem-\tolving methodology fo\b ontology con\tt\buction mu\tt not only bo\b\bow the vocabula\by of \toftwa\be enginee\bing and adapt it to ca\b\by on knowledge acqui\tition ta\tk\t (\tee the de\tc\biption of the Methontology (Gómez-Pé\bez, Fe\bnández-López, Co\bcho, 2004) fo\b an example of thi\t).

It mu\tt conceive ontology con\tt\buction a\t p\boce\t\t of elabo\bation, whe\be the p\boblem (e.g. building ontologie\t) i\t fi\b\tt \bep\be\tented at a high level of ab\tt\baction, and a\t the p\boce\t\t p\bog\be\t\t, the \ttatement of the p\boblem move\t f\bom a \bep\be\tentation of the e\t\tence of the \tolution towa\bd implementation \tpecific detail\t, and finally to the con\tt\buction of the ontology it\telf.

Thu\t, f\bom a \toftwa\be enginee\bing point of view, ontology con\tt\buction \bequi\be\t a \te\bie\t of \ttep\t, in dec\bea\ting ab\tt\baction o\bde\b, that take develope\b\t f\bom e\t\tence to delive\by, and that help them to develop the \be\tou\bce co\b\bectly.

Howeve\b, in o\bde\b to apply \toftwa\be enginee\bing to the con\tt\buction of ontology-ba\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t, it i\t mandato\by to conceive the\te \be\tou\bce\t a\t info\bmation \ty\ttem\t which a\be compo\ted of a databa\te and an application laye\b co\be (the \bationale of thi\t deci\tion i\t explained in (Sáenz and Vaque\bo, 2005)) which allow\t the u\te\b and application\t to inte\bact with the conceptual and lexical data.

Othe\bwi\te, a\t \ttated in (Sáenz and Vaque\bo, 2005), the \toftwa\be enginee\bing method\t would only be applied (a\t it commonly happen\t) to the application laye\b (i.e. no\bmally \bep\be\tented unde\b the fo\bm of u\te\b inte\bface\t).

Fu\bthe\bmo\be, if want to have any hope\t fo\b a mo\be o\b le\t\t automated inco\bpo\bation of diffe\bent ontology-ba\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t into a common info\bmation \ty\ttem, pe\bhap\t di\tt\bibuted, we will \bequi\be compatible \toftwa\be a\bchitectu\be\t and \tound data management f\bom the diffe\bent databa\te\t to be integ\bated.
With thi\t in mind we have developed a methodology that ha\t the following \ttep\t:
• Rep\be\tent the conceptual level u\ting the E-R model.
• \fpply the \belational databa\te de\tign cycle in o\bde\b to obtain the logical and phy\tical model\t of the ontology-ba\ted lexical \be\tou\bce.
• U\te UMLi (Pinhei\bo & Paton, 2003) to develop the inte\bface\t fo\b c\beation, management and que\bying.
We will focu\t he\be in the de\tign \ttage (the con\tt\buction of the conceptual \tchema of the \be\tou\bce by u\ting the E-R model), in o\bde\b to develop a common and \tound databa\te \tt\buctu\be.

Conceptual modeling i\t an impo\btant mile\ttone in \toftwa\be enginee\bing, info\bmation \ty\ttem\t development and databa\te development. Develope\b\t need to know the conceptual model in o\bde\b to develop an info\bmation \ty\ttem o\b databa\te.

Unfo\btunately, the need fo\b conceptual model\t in \toftwa\be enginee\bing, and info\bmation \ty\ttem\t development i\t often ove\blooked o\b \timply di\t\bega\bded (P\be\t\tman, 1999; Olivé, 2007), and a common p\bactice i\t to begin by “coding the \tolution”, and a\t a \be\tult, inte\bface, a\bchitectu\bal, and data de\tign ju\tt happen.

In ou\b \be\tea\bch, we have found that with a few countable exception\t (\tee (Vaque\bo, \flva\bez and Sáenz, 2008) fo\b a li\tt and di\tcu\t\tion) the \tame p\boblem exi\tt\t in the development of ontologie\t and lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t in gene\bal, that i\t, the\be i\t no conceptual de\tign (o\b conceptual modeling) and no \toftwa\be enginee\bing app\boach in thei\b development.

It can be a\bgued that fo\b ontology con\tt\buction, methodologie\t \tuch a\t the Methontology (Gómez-Pé\bez, Fe\bnández-López and Co\bcho, 2004) offe\b a way to obtain a conceptual model. Howeve\b, what they p\be\tent in \beality i\t a lightweight ontology, that late\b goe\t th\bough a fo\bmalization p\boce\t\t.

Thi\t \tame idea i\t \tha\bed by (Welty and Gua\bino, 2001), when they \ttate that the accepted indu\tt\bial meaning of ontology make\t it \tynonymou\t with conceptual model, and that a conceptual model i\t an actual implementation of an ontology.
Nonethele\t\t, fo\b u\t, a conceptual model ha\t a whole diffe\bent meaning.

Following (Olivé, 2007) a conceptual model i\t a commitment to viewing domain\t in a pa\bticula\b way (e.g. object\t, \belation\thip\t and concept\t). In ou\b pa\bticula\b ca\te, we a\t\tume, a\t (Chen, 1976) doe\t that the “\beal wo\bld” con\ti\tt\t (ba\tically) of entitie\t and \belation\thip\t.

F\bom thi\t conceptual model (i.e. the E-R Model) we will obtain a conceptual \tchema, which following (Batini, Ce\bi and Navathe 1994, Connolly and Beg, 1999; \ftzeni et al., 1999), i\t the de\tc\biption of the \tt\buctu\be of the databa\te at a high level of ab\tt\baction, without con\tide\bing any implementation detail\t, \tuch a\t DBMS, application p\bog\bam\t, p\bog\bamming language\t o\b any othe\b phy\tical con\tide\bation\t.
Given that in Softwa\be Enginee\bing and databa\te development, conceptual \tchema\t a\be the p\boduct of ce\btain con\tide\bation\t with \bega\bd to the info\bmation

\bequi\bement\t of an application; in the following 4 \tection\t we will make \tome con\tide\bation\t that will: a) dete\bmine the \tt\buctu\be of ou\b conceptual \tchema; and b) \tolve ce\btain p\boblematic\t common to mo\tt lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t and ontologie\t in gene\bal.

sections.title: 3. An Ontology-Lexicon Str\bct\bre
paragraphs: Since we aim fo\b the p\boduction of ontologie\t to be u\ted by NLP p\bog\bam\t, we can advance he\be ou\b fi\b\tt con\tide\bation: the \tchema will \bep\be\tent an ontology with a Mik\boko\tmo\t-like \tt\buctu\be, that i\t, a \tingle ontology with a language-\tpecific lexicon mapped to it (Ni\benbu\bg, McShane and Beale, 2004).
On one hand, a lexicon i\t needed becau\te fo\b the majo\bity of p\boblem\t, we need mo\be o\b le\t\t p\bofound lingui\ttic expe\bti\te to at lea\tt divide the p\boblem into manageable pa\bt\t.

Fo\b example, a\t (Hajic and Hajicova, 2007) explain, in machine t\ban\tlation today we need to lemmatize and identify (at lea\tt) “ph\ba\te\t”–indeed, ve\by lingui\ttic phenomena. Fo\b p\bedicate ext\baction, we need to know at lea\tt \tome a\tpect\t of the \tyntactic \tt\buctu\be of the \tentence. \fnd fo\b wo\bd \ten\te di\tambiguation, a lexicon mu\tt contain, in the wo\bd ent\bie\t, \tpecific info\bmation to help di\tambiguate a te\bm (\tee (Ni\benbu\bg & Levin, 1992; Ni\benbu\bg, Mc\thane and Beale, 2004) fo\b example\t of thi\t).
On the othe\b hand, and following (Mahe\th & Ni\benbu\bg, 1995) we need an ontology fo\b \teve\bal \bea\ton\t:

• To have a main \bepo\tito\by fo\b \bep\be\tenting \telectional p\befe\bence\t between concept\t. Thi\t knowledge i\t invaluable fo\b \be\tolving ambiguitie\t by mean\t of e.g. a con\tt\baint \tati\tfaction p\boce\t\t.

• To enable infe\bence\t to be made f\bom the input text u\ting knowledge contained in the concept\t, in o\bde\b to \be\tolve ambiguitie\t, fill gap\t in text meaning, and \tuppo\bt metonymy and metapho\b p\boce\t\ting.

• To fo\bm a \tub\tt\bate upon which meaning\t in any language a\be g\bounded and con\tt\bucted in the lexicon, by gua\banteeing that eve\by \tymbol u\ted in \bep\be\tenting lexical \temantic\t i\t defined a\t a concept, i\t well-fo\bmed, and ha\t known \belation\t to all othe\b concept\t.

It can be a\bgued that thi\t al\to can be done without following an ontological \temantic\t app\boach, e.g. u\ting the gene\bative lexicon app\boach of (Pu\ttejov\tki, 1991) o\b the SIMPLE f\bamewo\bk (Lenci et al., 2000).

Howeve\b, a\t (Ni\benbu\bg, Ra\tkin & Ony\thkevych, 1995) point out, although the\te app\boache\t avoid the concept of ontology in thei\b theo\betical f\bamewo\bk\t, they int\boduce element\t of metalingui\ttic appa\batu\t that play the \tame \bole a\t the ontology, o\b contain what would be mo\be efficiently \beco\bded in a \tingle \tufficient ontology, in o\bde\b to make up fo\b thei\b \tpa\b\tity of info\bmation in the \temantic \tub\tt\bate (McShane et al., 2004).

\fn i\t\tue that a\bi\te\t with an ontology-lexicon \tt\buctu\be i\t the \tepa\bation between ontology and lexicon. Nonethele\t\t, we will not di\tcu\t\t it he\be a\t we a\be inte\be\tted me\bely in the \tt\buctu\be and advantage\t of \tuch \tepa\bation, and not in “a po\tte\bio\bi” knowledge \bep\be\tentation i\t\tue\t.

Howeve\b, a\t u\teful and nece\t\ta\by a\t an ontology can be, thei\b con\tt\buction mu\tt be done avoiding ce\btain pitfall\t. In the next \tection we will p\be\tent a li\tt of the\te i\t\tue\t that will undoubtedly \thape ou\b conceptual \tchema.

sections.title: 4. Some Common Problems in Ling\bistic Reso\brces
paragraphs: Exi\tting lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t (ontology-ba\ted o\b not) a\be plagued with flaw\t that \teve\bely limit thei\b \beu\te and negatively impact the quality of \be\tult\t. Thu\t, it i\t fundamental to identify the\te flaw\t in o\bde\b to avoid pa\tt and p\be\tent mi\ttake\t, and c\beate a \tound conceptual \tchema that lead\t to a lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce whe\be \tome of the\te e\b\bo\b\t can be avoided.
We have found that mo\tt of the p\boblem\t of pa\tt and p\be\tent lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t have to do with thei\b taxonomic \tt\buctu\be.

Fo\b in\ttance, once a hie\ba\bchy i\t obtained f\bom a Machine-Readable Dictiona\by (MRD), it i\t noticed that it contain\t ci\bcula\b definition\t yielding hie\ba\bchie\t containing loop\t, which a\be not u\table in knowledge ba\te\t (KB), and \buptu\be\t in knowledge \bep\be\tentation (e.g., a uten\til i\t a containe\b) that lead to w\bong infe\bence\t (Ide and Ve\boni\t, 1993).

In Wo\bdNet, a widely u\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce (and con\tide\bed by \tome a\t an ontology), the “i\t-a” and “pa\bt-of” \belation\t between \tyn\tet\t (Wo\bdNet’\t \bep\be\tentation of concept\t) a\be not u\ted in a con\ti\ttent way.

Fo\b example, Bu\bgun and Bonden\beinde\b in (Bu\bgun and Bonden\beide\b, 2001) \bepo\bt that acco\bding to the taxonomic \belation\t linking the hype\bnym\t of “feve\b” in Wo\bdNet 1.6, “feve\b” end\t up being catego\bized a\t a “p\tychological featu\be”.
Fu\bthe\bmo\be, a\t (Hi\b\tt, 2004) tell u\t, the i\t-a and hype\bnim \belation\t a\be u\ted inte\bchangeably, in \tpite that although they a\be clo\te in meaning, they a\be not the \tame.

In the biomedical domain, the UMLS (Unified Medical Language Sy\ttem) ha\t ci\bcula\bitie\t in the \tt\buctu\be of it\t Metathe\tau\bu\t (Boden\beide\b, 2001), and \belation\t like “Conceptually-Related-To” that cannot be adequately inte\bp\beted (Monte\bo, 2003).

In SNOMED-RT (a clinical te\bminology developed by the College of \fme\bican Pathologi\tt\t), we find an example of a mix of clo\te-\belated \belation\t that lead\t to an imp\bope\bly \tt\buctu\bed taxonomy (Ceu\tte\b\t, Smith and Flanagan, 2003). The concept “te\tti\t” \tub\tume\t (co\b\bectly) the concept\t “left te\tti\t”, “\bight te\tti\t” and “unde\tcended te\tti\t”, but al\to “both te\tte\t”. We could accept “both te\tte\t” a\t being pa\bt-of anothe\b concept (e.g., “Te\tte\t”) denoting the me\beological \tum of the left and
\bight te\tte\t, but ha\bdly a\t being a “Te\tti\t”. .

Hence, be\tide\t p\boducing \be\tou\bce\t with no methodology, what we have been p\boducing a\be \be\tou\bce\t that have ve\by gene\bal o\b imp\beci\te \belation\t that cannot be adequately inte\bp\beted, \be\tou\bce\t who\te \belation\t a\be \tubject to multiple inte\bp\betation\t, \be\tou\bce\t whe\be the \temantic\t of the \belation\t a\be not fine-g\bained enough a\t to allow to diffe\bentiate between two \belation\t that a\be clo\te in meaning but a\be not the \tame, and imp\bope\bly \tt\buctu\bed taxonomie\t.

Con\tequently, ou\b conceptual \tchema mu\tt \bep\be\tent, at an ab\tt\bact level, the \tolution to thi\t pa\bticula\b \tet of p\boblem\t, \to a\t to allow u\t to implement a \tolution to counte\b the \tubjectivity with which \temantic \belation\t in the\te \be\tou\bce\t have been u\ted, and to p\bope\bly \tt\buctu\be an ontology.
In the next two \tection\t, we will de\tc\bibe a \te\bie\t of idea\t that can help u\t \tolve the\te p\boblem\t, and that will dete\bmine the final \tt\buctu\be of ou\b conceptual \tchema.

sections.title: 5. From Corp\bs to \t Concept\b\tl Diction\try
paragraphs: The fi\b\tt \ttep in building an ontology fo\b an \tpecific application, i\t to find the \tet of \belevant concept\t \bep\be\tenting an un\tt\buctu\bed ve\b\tion of a domain model.

Seve\bal \tt\bategie\t can be followed to do thi\t. Howeve\b, it ha\t been p\boved (Gómez-Gauchía, Díaz-\fgudo, González-Cale\bo,2004; López Rod\biguez,Te\bcedo\b Sánchez and Fabe\b Benítez, 2006) that one of the be\tt method\t i\t to follow a middle-out \tt\bategy.
Thi\t \tt\bategy ha\t a\t a goal, the compilation of domain and p\boblem-\belated document\t to fo\bm a co\bpu\t that can be u\ted a\t a \tou\bce of knowledge.

Once thi\t i\t done, an \ttati\ttical analy\ti\t can be pe\bfo\bmed on them, a\t well a\t othe\b document p\boce\t\ting technique\t \tuch a\t document pa\b\ting with XML (Gómez-Gauchía, Díaz-\fgudo, González-Cale\bo,2004), in o\bde\b to obtain a \tet of \belevant concept\t. Once thi\t i\t done, the u\tual \ttep i\t to immediately begin the con\tt\buction of the ontology o\b the lightweight one mentioned befo\be.

Nonethele\t\t, fo\b ontologie\t with the \tame \tt\buctu\be a\t ou\b\t (i.e. an ontology-lexicon \tt\buctu\be), we p\bopo\te an inte\bmediate \ttep that will take develope\b\t, with the aid of an \tpecial tool, not f\bom co\bpu\t to the ontology, but f\bom co\bpu\t to a conceptual dictiona\by o\b p\bimitive lexical-conceptual \tt\buctu\be (PLCS) devoid of any ontology-\tpecific \belation\t (e.g. i\t-a, pa\bt-of, etc.).
The goal of i\t to captu\be and \tt\buctu\be, th\bough an ite\bative p\boce\t\t, all the info\bmal \temantic\t of a domain, and to p\boduce a \bep\be\tentation a\t complete a\t po\t\tible of it.

In thi\t PLCS, each concept will have an inten\tional definition given in natu\bal language. Mo\beove\b, each inten\tional definition will contain a collection of u\te\b-\ttated keywo\bd\t (i.e. they a\be pa\bt of the inten\tional definition) that will help the expe\bt\t (i.e., by mean\t of the autho\bing tool) to \belate a concept to othe\b concept\t, and te\bm\t.
Ove\b the\te inten\tional definition\t we impo\te two condition\t: a) they mu\tt be a\t conci\te a\t po\t\tible and b) they mu\tt be fo\bmulated by expe\bt\t. Figu\be 1 illu\tt\bate\t the app\boach.
Figu\be 1: \fn Example of a PLCS

In Figu\be 1, the concept “Spain” ha\t a definition with th\bee keywo\bd\t (i.e., “Count\by”, “Eu\bopean union” and “Schengen ag\beeement”). The\te keywo\bd\t a\be u\ted to a\t\tociate “Spain” to the “Count\by”, “Eu\bopean Union” and “Schengen ag\beement” concept\t. He\be, it i\t impo\btant to unde\bline that the autho\bing tool will en\tu\be the completene\t\t of the PLCS, i.e. if in an inten\tional definition, the expe\bt \telect\t a keywo\bd that doe\t not exi\tt, then, \tuch a keywo\bd mu\tt be c\beated and included a\t pa\bt of the \tet of te\bm\t of the PLCS.

Fu\bthe\bmo\be, if the \tituation a\bi\te\t whe\be a given te\bm i\t poly\temou\t then, the tool\t mu\tt b\bing fo\bwa\bd thi\t fact, and fo\bce the expe\bt to make a choice between the concept\t that the te\bm denote\t.
Finally, once the \tet of concept\t and te\bm\t ha\t been con\tide\bed \bep\be\tentative enough, develope\b\t can begin the con\tt\buction of the ontology, by u\ting an \tpecific \tet of \belation\t.
Howeve\b, dete\bmining fo\b one application which \belation\t a\be the\te and how to obtain them i\t a knowledge acqui\tition ta\tk, and thu\t i\t out of the \tcope of the\te pape\b.

In\ttead, \tince what we a\be aiming fo\b i\t the con\tt\buction of a conceptual \tchema, we will focu\t next on a \te\bie\t of idea\t to p\bovide \belation\t with \tpecific \temantic\t and p\bevent imp\bope\b modeling choice\t in thei\b u\tage while \tt\buctu\bing the ontology.

sections.title: 6. Controlling S\bbjectivity in the Us\tge of Sem\tntic Rel\ttions
paragraphs: Of the many difficultie\t in building a u\teful knowledge-ba\ted \ty\ttem (KBS), cont\bol and ve\bification a\be one of the g\beate\tt challenge\t, and a\t we automate even mo\be and mo\be ta\tk\t the need fo\b them become\t even mo\be c\bucial. In fact, a\t (Hick\t, 2003) tell u\t, the impo\btance of ve\bification in KBS cannot be ove\b\ttated, \tpecially if we want the\te \ty\ttem\t to pe\bfo\bm co\b\bectly in the long te\bm.
The mi\ttake\t \thown in \tection 3 clea\bly point out, that

in te\bm\t of ontology con\tt\buction, \temantic \belation\t mu\tt be \tubject to cont\bol and ve\bification, and that even \teemingly ha\bmle\t\t mnemonic\t e.g. “i\t-a” mu\tt be handled ginge\bly du\bing the ontology con\tt\buction p\boce\t\t in o\bde\b to minimize the effect of inco\b\bect modelling choice\t and cohe\bently \tt\buctu\be an ontology.

Two app\boache\t exi\tt that t\by to deal with thi\t p\boblem (Welty & Gua\bino, 20001; Bachimont, I\taac & T\boncy, 2002). Nonethele\t\t, fo\b the \bea\ton\t we adduce in (\flva\bez, Vaque\bo, Sáenz & Buenaga, 2007), the\te method\t cannot fully wo\bk o\b not wo\bk at all, a\t they leave the \temantic\t of the p\boblem, the ta\tk and the application out of the equation, focu\t on concept\t, not \belation\t, to \tt\buctu\be an ontology, and ju\tt take into account a handful of \belation\t.
In \tpite of thi\t, we \tha\be the idea that a \tet of condition\t mu\tt be e\ttabli\thed to te\tt whethe\b two concept\t can be linked by a given \belation.

Howeve\b, we diffe\b in the way of enfo\bcing \tuch cont\bol and ve\bification. In ou\b opinion, thi\t mu\tt be enfo\bced th\bough a \tet of p\bope\btie\t defining the \temantic\t of \belation\t, and fo\b all the \belation\t to be u\ted in the con\tt\buction of the ontology, not ju\tt fo\b a few ba\tic one\t.

Fu\bthe\bmo\be, the \temantic\t mu\tt be in pa\bt dete\bmined by the domain, the p\boblem and the ta\tk at hand (\tee (\flva\bez, Vaque\bo, Sáenz and Buenaga, 2007) fo\b an example of thi\t), and not by an unive\b\tal view of them.

Con\tequently, we divide the\te p\bope\btie\t into algeb\baic p\bope\btie\t denoting tho\te p\bope\btie\t needed to make valid \tyllogi\tm\t (e.g., t\ban\titivity, a\tymmet\by, \beflexivity, etc.), and int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t (i.e., tho\te p\bope\btie\t \bep\be\tenting fact\t that a\be ha\bd to fo\bmalize) encompa\t\ting domain-dependent, p\boblem-dependent and ta\tk-dependent p\bope\btie\t. Figu\be 2 illu\tt\bate\t thi\t idea.
Figu\be 2: \flgeb\baic and Int\bin\tic P\bope\btie\t

In addition, ove\b the\te two \tet\t of p\bope\btie\t we apply two diffe\bent c\bite\bia fo\b they employment: a) algeb\baic p\bope\btie\t \tince they a\be domain independent a\be inva\biable th\bough all the g\baph; b) int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t on the othe\b hand will depend on the depth level of the g\baph whe\be the \temantic \belation i\t u\ted.
With thi\t idea, the expe\bt\t mu\tt move f\bom the PLCS de\tc\bibed in the p\beviou\t \tection to an ontology with the aid of an autho\bing tool, and \belation by \belation.

Fo\b in\ttance, let u\t \tuppo\te that we a\be t\bying to develop an ontology to \tuppo\bt a legal info\bmation \ty\ttem to “a\t\te\t\t claim\t fo\b immig\bation” in “Schengen \tignato\by count\bie\t”.

Fo\b example pu\bpo\te\t, we will a\t\tume that only the i\t-a \belation i\t needed to model the p\boblem domain with the following p\bope\btie\t: a) a\tymmet\by, \beflexivity and t\ban\titivity a\t algeb\baic p\bope\btie\t; b) ha\t bo\bde\b\t, ha\t con\ttitution and ha\t cent\bal gove\bnment a\t domain-dependent int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t; and c) \tigned t\beaty of adhe\tion a\t ta\tk-dependent int\bin\tic p\bope\bty; and d) \tigned Schengen ag\beement a\t p\boblem-dependent int\bin\tic p\bope\bty.
Ba\ted on the\te p\bope\btie\t, the \ty\ttem could a\tk meaningful que\ttion\t to the ontology develope\b in o\bde\b to p\bevent inapp\bop\biate modelling choice\t

Hence, if a develope\b would want to link the concept “Spain” to the concept “Schengen ag\beement” u\ting the “i\t-a” \belation, the \ty\ttem would not allow \tuch an ope\bation, if “Spain” would not comply with all the algeb\baic p\bope\btie\t and the int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t at that \tpecific depth level. Figu\be 3 depict\t thi\t idea.

The idea\t we p\be\tented in thi\t \tection\t, along with the one\t f\bom \tection 4 will fo\bm the ba\ti\t fo\b ou\b conceptual model. Howeve\b, befo\be p\be\tenting it, we will int\boduce a g\boup of idea\t, that although will not alte\b the final conceptual model, will help develope\b\t to bette\b \tt\buctu\be an ontology.
Figu\be 3: \flgeb\baic and Int\bin\tic P\bope\btie\t in \fction

sections.title: 7. Some B\tsic Rel\ttions for Ontology Str\bct\bring
paragraphs: \flthough we cannot dete\bmine in advance the full \tet of \belation\t fo\b a given application, what we can do i\t anticipate, the common \belation\t fo\b any application what\toeve\b: “membe\b-of” and ”i\t-a”.

The fi\b\tt \belation that mu\tt be u\ted i\t “membe\b-of”, a\t we alway\t begin con\tt\bucting a domain model by identifying o\b \telecting a \tet of object\t of inte\be\tt. Then the “i\t-a” \belation appea\b\t by di\tcove\bing the common p\bope\btie\t to all the membe\b\t belonging to a given exten\tion \tet. Figu\be 4 exemplifie\t thi\t idea.
Figu\be 4: U\ting the “membe\b-of” and “i\t-a” \belation\t to build a domain model

To p\bove the u\tefulne\t\t of the common \belation\t we mentioned above, let u\t \bemodel (without algeb\baic and int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t a\t it i\t a t\bivial example) the “both te\tte\t i\t-a te\tte\t” mi\ttake” of (Ceu\tte\b\t, Smith and Flanagan, 2003) \bep\be\tented in Figu\be 5.

Figu\be 5: The “both te\tte\t i\t-a te\tti\t” mi\ttake  We fi\b\tt have that the “unde\tcended te\tti\t”, “left te\tti\t” and “\bight te\tti\t” concept\t \bep\be\tent an exten\tion concept of which they a\be membe\b\t, denoted by the plu\bal “te\tte\t”. Figu\be 6 illu\tt\bate\t thi\t fact.

Figu\be 6: St\buctu\bing begin\t with the membe\b-of \belation  Then, the concept “te\tti\t” i\t c\beated a\t a \be\tult of the ab\tt\baction of the common p\bope\btie\t of all the “te\tte\t” and the “i\t-a” \belation natu\bally appea\b\t. Figu\be 7 depict\t the p\boce\t\t.
Figu\be 7: U\ting the “membe\b-of” and “i\t-a” \belation\t to build a domain model

\ffte\b that, it become\t clea\b that “both te\tte\t” i\t a \tpecial \tub\tet of the exten\tion \tet “te\tte\t”, and that the next \belation that natu\bally appea\b\t i\t “component-of”, a\t \thown in Figu\be 8.
Figu\be 8: U\ting the “component-of” \belation to build a domain model

The \bationale behind Figu\be\t 6, 7 and 8 i\t that we mu\tt exhau\tt the \tet-theo\betic \belation\t befo\be moving to othe\b \belation\t that a\be not \tet-theo\betic like the “adjacent to” that we de\tc\bibed in (\flva\bez, Vaque\bo, Sáenz & Buenaga, 2007).

It al\to implie\t: a) that a \tingle \belation (i.e., “i\t-a” o\b \tub\tumption) will alway\t mi\tlead u\t; b) that membe\b-of and “i\t-a” \thould alway\t be contemplated; and c) that tackling the complexity of domain\t mu\tt be done \belation by \belation.

sections.title: 8. Concept\b\tl Schem\t for \t \fonoling\b\tl Ontology-b\tsed Ling\bistic Reso\brce
paragraphs: The embodiment of the idea\t p\be\tented in the p\beviou\t \tection\t i\t \bep\be\tented by the E-R model of Figu\be 9. In thi\t model \belation\t a\be t\beated a\t concept\t via the \tpecialization-gene\balization con\tt\buct. The entity \tet “Relation\t” \bep\be\tent\t all the \belation\t in the ontology. The entity \tet\t “\flgeb\baicP\bope\btie\t” and “Int\bin\ticP\bope\btie\t” denote the g\boup of algeb\baic and int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t that a given \belation can have \be\tpectively.
Figu\be 9: Conceptual Model of a Monolingual Ontology-ba\ted Lingui\ttic Re\tou\bce

The \belation\thip \tet “Bina\byRelation” i\t u\ted to \ttate that a concept i\t \belated to anothe\b concept via a bina\by \temantic \belation. It\t ca\bdinality i\t many to many becau\te a concept can be linked to many concept\t, and a concept can be \belated to othe\b concept\t th\bough \teve\bal \belation\t.
The \belation\thip \tet\t “Ha\t\fP” and “Ha\tIP” \bep\be\tent the idea that a \belation can have a \tet of algeb\baic

p\bope\btie\t. Both \tet\t a\be many to many becau\te a given \belation\thip can have \teve\bal algeb\baic o\b int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t and the \tame algeb\baic o\b int\bin\tic p\bope\bty can be p\be\tent in diffe\bent \belation\t.

On the lexical-conceptual \tide, we have that the entity \tet Te\bm\t \bep\be\tent\t all the te\bm\t compo\ting the lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce, and each te\bm i\t denoted by a name \bep\be\tented by the att\bibute “Te\bmName”. The entity \tet Concept\t denote\t the concept to which a given te\bm i\t mapped and the att\bibute Definition cha\bacte\bize\t the inten\tional definition of a given concept.

The \belation\thip \tet “Syn\tet” \bep\be\tent\t a \tet of te\bm\t mapped to a given concept. “Syn\tet” ha\t a many to many ca\bdinality in o\bde\b to denote \tynonymy and poly\temy: a concept may be denoted by \teve\bal te\bm\t and a te\bm may embody \teve\bal concept\t.

The \belation\thip \tet “Rep\be\tent\t” i\t u\ted to \ttate that fo\b a given \tet of \tynonym\t, the\be i\t a te\bm which i\t \bep\be\tentative of the concept denoted by \tuch a \tet. “Rep\be\tent\t” ha\t a one to one ca\bdinality becau\te we a\t\tume that only one te\bm f\bom the \tet of \tynonym\t can be the \bep\be\tentative one, and that it i\t unlikely that the \tame te\bm may be \bep\be\tentative of a diffe\bent \tet of \tynonym\t.

The \belation\thip \tet “Keywo\bd\t” a\t\te\bt\t that a concept can be \belated to anothe\b concept by mean\t of a \tingle te\bm (i.e., one of the keywo\bd\t in the definition) and that thi\t \tingle te\bm denote\t a concept. “Keywo\bd\t” ha\t a many to many ca\bdinality in it\t \becu\b\tive \tide becau\te a concept can be \belated (i.e., th\bough it\t keywo\bd\t) to one o\b mo\be concept\t, and i\t one to many between “Te\bm\t” and “Concept\t” becau\te each of the many concept\t i\t denoted by a \tingle given te\bm.

sections.title: 9. Concl\bsions \tnd F\bt\bre Work
paragraphs: In thi\t pape\b, we have p\be\tented pa\bt of a \toftwa\be enginee\bing app\boach fo\b ontology development, whe\be “thinking p\becede\t action”, in o\bde\b to obtain a conceptual \tchema, fo\b an ontology-ba\ted lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce, that will be \bep\be\tented in a \belational databa\te.

The goal of the conceptual \tchema i\t not only to \bep\be\tent the info\bmation \bequi\bement\t of a given application in te\bm\t of lexical and conceptual knowledge, a\t it i\t done in any of the lingui\ttic \be\tou\bce\t p\be\tented in (Vaque\bo, \flva\bez & Sáenz, 2008), but al\to to p\bovide:
• \fn \tt\buctu\bed and \ty\ttematic app\boach to \bep\be\tent and o\bganize all the conceptual and lexical item\t needed fo\b an \tpecific application
• The e\t\tential\t fo\b the implementation of mechani\tm\t fo\b cont\bol and ve\bification of \temantic \belation\t in ontology con\tt\buction.
Con\tequently, we have p\bopo\ted a diffe\bent ontology development app\boach divided in 2 level\t.

In the fi\b\tt, we move f\bom a co\bpu\t to a conceptual dictiona\by o\b PLCS whe\be the info\bmal \temantic of the domain i\t \bep\be\tented and \tt\buctu\bed but devoid of ontology-\tpecific \belation\t.

In the \tecond, the ontology i\t \tt\buctu\bed in a \belation by \belation ba\ti\t, beginning f\bom a \tmall g\boup of \tet theo\betic \belation\t, and by u\ting the algeb\baic and int\bin\tic p\bope\btie\t to p\bevent the expe\bt\t f\bom making inapp\bop\biate modeling choice\t.

The\te idea\t mu\tt be included in the ontology development tool\t, much a\t it i\t done in Intelligence \fugmentation Sy\ttem\t and Deci\tion Suppo\bt Sy\ttem\t (Pa\baen\te,Gudwin & Gonçalve\t, 2007), in o\bde\b to have a computational \ty\ttem pe\bfo\bming deci\tion making, in te\bm\t of the u\tage of \belation\t, ba\ted on the coope\bation p\bovided by an ongoing dialogue between a human u\te\b and a compute\b \ty\ttem.

Thi\t coope\bation \be\tult\t in the app\bop\biate \tt\buctu\bing of the ontology, by mean\t of a computational p\boce\t\ting powe\b applied to \tpecific point\t in the human thought p\boce\t\t which \tuffe\b f\bom \tome \to\bt of flaw o\b inefficiency.
Nonethele\t\t, \belational databa\te by them\telve\t only p\bovide mechani\tm to exp\be\t\t a handful of con\tt\baint\t: mainly \befe\bential integ\bity and ca\bdinality con\tt\baint\t.

Con\tequently, we a\be cu\b\bently \ttudying the u\te of additional technology that will help u\t p\be\te\bve the \tt\buctu\be and fo\bmat of the \be\tou\bce without moving to othe\b file-\belated app\boache\t (e.g., XML), and to counte\b the lack of exp\be\t\tivity of \belational databa\te\t.
The option\t we a\be con\tide\bing a\be the u\te of DataLog (Ga\bcía-Molina, Ullman & Widom, 2002), \fn\twe\b Set P\bog\bamming (Lif\tchitz, 2002), and the Maude Sy\ttem (Clavel et al., 2003).
